text: [Music] [Music] my little elves Chalmers tractor and my bifold wheeler rake and after I cut the Hey ladies in the field flat like what you see down here and down there's a little bit of fun raked area a rake out the field take these rows that were cut and then rate flips the rows over so that the the underside of the grass is now exposed to the Sun so that that dries and it also merges it up into a room that's small enough with the hay baler and pick it up this is what we call window a great for to help the underside of the roll dry so you just flip it over and also merged it together so that come in here later this afternoon with a hay baler it'll pick it up in daily you know what I'm doing here is that now I rake when there's what I'm gonna do on the ground so that right here the leaves of the old fella and the grasses don't all fall off they get too dry and brittle and as you move them lose all that leaf and you can lose your own easily 2030 percent of the biomass that you're trying to get into a veil so right now then I have to wait for a couple hours for it to dry I'm still a little bit dry and still waiting for the do last nights due to come off it's all gonna depend on if we get enough Sun the day forecast kind of changed a little bit so you got three fathers guys number one thing on drying hay is the amount of sunlight in the humidity so it won't pass today usually below 50% anything 55 or greater percent that's real hot muggy day high dew point kidney and everything goes around I'll be here this afternoon [Music] [Music] [Applause] so your round bailing today yeah this personnel but weather forecast kinda he's grateful to Chuck well you can cover a lot of ground [Music] [Music] [Music] [Applause] [Music]
